Author: Chip Conley
Profile Headline: Founder at Modern Elder Academy
Post Body: A Mentor is a Librarian and a Confidante.During my seven and a half years of full-time and part-time leadership and advisory work at Airbnb, I was fortunate to be in more than one hundred mentor relationships. Often, I was a ‚Äúmentern,‚Äù a mentor, and an intern at the same time. I was learning as much from these young folks (almost all Millennials) as they were from me. When I‚Äôm overwhelmed with inputs, I tend to categorize things. With this firehose of mentorship opportunities cascading my way, I stumbled upon a convenient way to understand the two broad types of mentorship.When a mentee sees you as a subject matter expert, you are a Librarian. That may not sound sexy, but your know-how and know-who are exceptionally valuable. At Airbnb, a data scientist trying to propose a pricing mechanism for hosts might ask me about the tools hotels use to optimize their guest room pricing. When I was this kind of mentor, the mentee asked the questions, I answered them, and often directed the mentee to articles, white papers, books, and people who could give them a deeper dive into this subject. On average, this kind of relationship with a mentee lasted three sessions. It was finite. They were looking for answers that, hopefully, I could supply.The other kind of mentorship relationship tends to be more personal. Your role as the Confidante is to help your mentee understand themselves more as a human. Instead of you answering the questions, you‚Äôre more often asking the questions. I‚Äôll never forget when one of my Airbnb direct reports told me I was her Confidante. I laughed and told her she hadn‚Äôt shared any juicy details with me yet. She responded, ‚ÄúIn my part of France, a confidante is the one who gives you confidence. You help me see what I do well and what needs work, along with a roadmap of how I can improve.‚Äù This kind of relationship is far from finite as it may last months or years, and you may have a life-altering impact on this mentee‚Äôs life. In sum, not all mentorships fit neatly into one or the other type as, in some, you might start as a Librarian and evolve into a Confidante. But, I‚Äôve found this categorization to be immensely clarifying in helping me understand how I might best serve my mentee.

Author: Matthew Sharp
Profile Headline: Data Pioneer | Recovering Data Scientist
Post Body: Clean Code tip for Data Scientists:Avoid the word ‚Äúdata‚Äù in codeThe word data is just so... generic.  It doesn't actually tell you anything.  As a data scientist everything you do involves data.  So much so, I've seen hundreds of notebooks where the word is splattered everywhere like a valley girl sprinkling the word 'like' in every sentence--data this, data that.  It's really unnecessary.Don't use `cars_data` or `cars_df`  just use `cars`.Don't use `query_data` use `query_{table_name}`.Don't use `save_data` do `save_to_csv`.  Don't use `plot_data` use `plot_bar_chart`.This is only a few examples but I hope you get the picture.  Try to be specific and your code will become clearer.That data represents something so use those words instead.  Often times you can get a good idea of better words to use by looking at database table names.  If you are creating a helper function that will work on lots of different datasets, try to focus on the operation you are doing.As a note: avoid using alternate synonyms too.  Words like "info", "facts", "details" should also be avoided.#CleanCode #DataScience #DataEngineering

In fact, sometimes it's the series of small wins that, over time, provide greater value than a big-win that takes too long to resolve.Business stakeholders want to see quick ROIs. If your modeling project moves at a snail's pace - taking more than 3 months to solve end-to-end, then it raises questions about the efficiency of your project deliverable. Find a smaller project that takes 2 to 3 months to deliver. Build the framework, and replicate the process from one team to the next.ùü∞. ùó¶ùòÅùóÆùòÅùó≤-ùóºùó≥-ùòÅùóµùó≤-ùóÆùóøùòÅ ùóÆùóπùó¥ùóºùóøùó∂ùòÅùóµùó∫ ùòÅùóøùó∂ùòÇùó∫ùóΩùóµùòÄ ùóºùòÉùó≤ùóø ùòÄùó∂ùó∫ùóΩùóπùó≤ ùóÆùóπùó¥ùóºùóøùó∂ùòÅùóµùó∫ùòÄMaybe, but not always. You have to consider the deliverable time it takes to research and apply the state-of-the-art algorithm. Even if the latest algorithm provides a 3 to 5% gain in performance, if it takes too long to apply and productionize, you may want to choose a simple algorithm.Deliver your project in phases. Starting with the MVP phase that applies a simple algorithm. Once you provide the initial value to the business, incrementally increase the quality of the model over time.ùü±. ùó¨ùóºùòÇ ùòÑùó∂ùóπùóπ ùóÆùóπùòÑùóÆùòÜùòÄ ùóØùó≤ ùó±ùóºùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÄùóºùó∫ùó≤ùòÅùóµùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóªùó≤ùòÑUnless you are pursuing a research role focused on pushing the frontier of new techniques in data science, for most roles, the reality is that some aspects of the job will get repetitive.That's because most problems, whether your role is based on recommendation, fraud, finance, forecasting, or product, already have procedures that follow the best practice.From one project to the next, you will end up importing a large chunk of your code used in the previous project.Hope you find the insights helpful! Post Body: +++ Why do we need a sociotechnical perspective for trustworthy AI and what does this mean in practice? +++It's a wrap üé¨ - Amir Mikail and I just gave our presentation at this year's #isaca2022 and we had a blast üéâ . (If you missed it, check out our AWK Group AG Trustworthy AI Masterclass, which Belinda M√ºller and I will be conducting on November 30 4pm-6pm. Tickets are available here: https://lnkd.in/e25-jGuQ )I particularly liked the questions from the audience:üë©‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è If we are fully compliant with future regulation of the EU AI Act, what are we still missing?üëâ Given our experience with GDPR, being compliant with regulations will allow us to cover the basics. However, there is always some wiggle room, when it comes to interpreting legal texts. Take dark patterns for example - here we are clearly in the realm of ethics and conflicting incentives. We expect similar effects with future AI regulation. üëâ In a quickly developing field such as AI and other emerging technologies, regulation will always lag behind technological developments. Therefore, we will not reach a state where we will be "done" with trustworthy AI by complying to current regulatory rules.üë©‚Äçüíº Who is accountable for AI failures and how can we make sure that we mitigate AI risks on a day to day basis?üëâ Accountability cannot lie with individual data scientists, however we can create structures that allow us to mitigate risks in our daily operations. Data Science best practices such as pair coding allow both for two sets of eyes to check a code and to make sure that knowledge transfer is guaranteed in case of individual data scientists leaving.üëâ While the role of ethics boards is important to anchor trustworthy AI in organizations, accountability must exist on the executive level, which might be represented in such a board. As the WEF points out, new roles such as Chief AI (Ethics) officers will be created in the future reflecting this importance.üè≠  Is trustworthy AI relevant in non-client facing use cases e.g., in the manufacturing sector? üëâ When we think about trustworthy AI we tend to think of use cases where AI systems have given discriminatory recommendations. However, some trustworthy AI system characterisitcs such as safety and security also apply to use cases that don't use personal data. üëâ  Critical infrastructure are another exmaple, where trustworthy AI plays a role. This is reflected in the current draft of the EU AI Act, which lists these cases as potential high-risk use cases. If you enjoyed our session, you might like tomorrow's session on Auditing blockchain by our amazing colleagues Maria Sommerhalder and Stefan Preuss.Amir Mikail, Belinda M√ºller and I will be around today and tomorrow and are looking forward to discussing all things #trustworthyAI with you!

Author: Denis Stark
Profile Headline: WAY4 Superhero ‚≠êÔ∏è with 20+ years in Payments & Cards | WAY4 Environment & Release Management | Automation | Solution architecture | Issuing | Acquiring | WAY4 trainings
Post Body: What I miss the most working with WAY4? There is one thing I‚Äôm coming back to again and again in my thoughts throughout my career. I can't remember when it comes to me for the first time. But I can tell that at least several times a week I‚Äôm thinking about it.If you are a programmer you probably guess what it is. Where are you going with all your questions or errors while developing or debugging your code? Obviously to Stack Overflow. Anything from powershall to python packages, from flutter plugins to telegram bot api you can find answers there. Everything but WAY4.Nowadays instead of reading documentation people just try, get an error and resolve it by looking into Stack Overflow. By saying Stack Overflow I mean this approach in general. It might be GitHub if we are talking about open source projects or Kaggle for data scientists. The idea is to use the power of community for the benefit of everyone.Let's say you have an error or struggle with some difficult task. Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve spent 4 hours to resolve it by reading documentation, analyzing logs and trying several options. Imagine there are other 10 people who struggle with the same issue. In an absence of community and cooperation each of them also spend 4 hours to resolve the same issue. 40 precious hours of people's lives are wasted. Such a shame!I‚Äôm not naive. I know that there are several obstacles. First the problem of freerider. Such systems tend to exploit most active members for the benefit of more lazy ones. Second intellectual properties. To what extent an employee of one organization is allowed to share results of his work to the community, knowing that this info can be used for the benefit of another organization? Third is the scale. How many users needed to have it beneficial?I know that companies are trying to resolve it at least on an organizational level. Each company I was working for had a corporate wiki (confluence) to keep know-how and issue tracker (jira) to track the issues. However the level of reuse within one single organization is obviously an order of magnitude less. There are 100+ companies using WAY4, so I guess it might be around 1000 people who work with this platform day to day. I guess we all are facing more or less the same situations and wasting time to resolve something already resolved by someone somewhere.It‚Äôs hard to explain this thing to people who never use Stack Overflow. And it doesn‚Äôt require any explanation for people who do. Every time I‚Äôm getting a solution there I feel how smart and powerful the community is. It's an amazing feeling of synergy and balance.Do you believe it‚Äôs possible to implement for WAY4? What obstacles do you see?#way4 #community
